stem: The pediatric clinic nurse is reviewing care plans for four children. Based on the documentation, match each child's need with the most appropriate interdisciplinary service.

tabs.title: Patient Information
tabs.content:
Patient A: 2-year-old with significant language delay (no words). Born at 28 weeks gestation.
Patient B: 7-year-old with Type 1 Diabetes. Parents are concerned about the school nurse not being available for lunch-time insulin administration.
Patient C: 5-year-old undergoing a painful bone marrow aspiration tomorrow in the hospital. He is very anxious and scared of needles.
Patient D: 14-year-old with Cystic Fibrosis. She is struggling with her identity and refusing to do her chest physiotherapy.

tabs.title: Available Support Services
tabs.content:
Early Intervention (EI): Provides services for children 0-3 years with developmental delays.
Section 504 / IEP: School accommodations for chronic illnesses and learning disabilities.
Child Life Specialist: Provides support for hospitalized children, including procedural preparation and coping strategies.
School Counselor / Teen Clinic: Offers adolescent psychosocial support and counseling services.

rows.text: A 2-year-old with a language delay requiring home-based early therapy.
A 7-year-old needing an insulin administration plan at school.
A 5-year-old needing preparation for a painful procedure using medical play.
A 14-year-old with a chronic illness struggling with identity.

rationale.correct: Early Intervention (EI) is the appropriate service for children aged 0-3 with developmental delays (r1). A Section 504 plan or IEP provides accommodations for children with chronic illnesses, such as diabetes, to receive necessary care at school (r2). Child Life Specialists utilize medical play and other techniques to reduce anxiety and prepare children for medical procedures (r3). Adolescent counselors offer psychosocial support to teenagers struggling with identity issues related to chronic illnesses (r4).
clinicalPearls: Early Intervention is the primary service for children under 3 with developmental delays.
A 504 plan focuses on accommodations, while an IEP addresses educational needs.
Child Life Specialists are experts in providing developmentally appropriate care in hospital settings.

questionTrap.trap: Referring a hospitalized child with procedural fear to a psychiatrist as the first intervention.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize the Child Life Specialist, who is trained in developmentally appropriate hospital care and procedural preparation.

mnemonic.title: EI for Early Years
mnemonic.expansion: Remember that EI (Early Intervention) is designed for the early years, specifically from birth through age 3.
